Applicative
Applicative :: module

Provides functions for working with applicative-style computations using Result values.  Allows for combining multiple Result-wrapped computations while handling errors gracefully.

Functions
apply
apply :: (
mf,
ma
)

Applies a Result-wrapped to a Result-wrapped value.

If both mf and ma are Result.ok, it returns Result.ok(f(a)).  If mf is an error, it returns mf.  If mf is ok but ma is an error, it returns ma.

Example
apply(Result.ok(|x| -> x + 1), Result.ok(2)) == Result.ok(3)
map2
map2 :: (
ma,
mb,
fx
)

Applies a binary to two Result values.  This is sugar over chaining apply twice.

Example
map2(Result.ok(2), Result.ok(3), |a, b| -> a + b) == Result.ok(5)
thenIgnoreLeft
thenIgnoreLeft :: (
fa,
fb
)

Sequences two Result computations, discards the result of the first.  This functions is mostly known as then `*>` operator

Example
thenIgnoreLeft(Result.ok(1), Result.ok(2)) == Result.ok(2)
thenIgnoreRight
thenIgnoreRight :: (
fa,
fb
)

Sequences two Result computations, discards the result of the second.  This functions is mostly known as then `<*` operator Example:

thenIgnoreRight(Result.ok(1), Result.ok(2)) == Result.ok(1)
pure
pure :: (
v
)

Wraps a raw value into the applicative context.

Equivalent to

Result.ok(v)
lift2
lift2 :: (
fx,
a,
b
)

Lifts a binary to operate over two Result values.

Example
lift2(|a, b| -> a + b, Result.ok(1), Result.ok(2)) == Result.ok(3)
sequence
sequence :: (
results
 = 
[]
)

Transforms a list of Result values into a Result of a list.  If any element is an error, the first error is returned.

Example
sequence([Result.ok(1), Result.ok(2)]) == Result.ok([1, 2])
traverse
traverse :: (
xs
 = 
[],
fx
)

Maps a over a list and sequences the results.  Useful for transforming a list of values into a Result of a list, where the returns Result.

Example
traverse([1, 2, 3], |x| -> Result.ok(x * 2)) == Result.ok([2, 4, 6])
